Question: Write and read multiple byte[] in file with Java: :I have to write byte arrays in a file. I can't do it in one time so I can't put my arrays in a container. Also the size of my arrays is variable.Secondly, the file is very huge, so I have to split it, in order to read it array by array.How can I do that ? I tried to write line by line my byte arrays  but I haven't been able. How can I put a separator between my arrays and after split it over this separator ?EDIT : I tried this :ByteArrayOutputStream bos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();ObjectOutput out = new ObjectOutputStream(bos);out.writeObject(byteArray);But, I execute this code several times, so the ObjectOutputStream adds each time a new header which corrupt the file.I also try : out.write(byteArray);but I couldn't separate my arrays. So I tried to append a '\n', which didn't work. After I was looking for library like FileUtils in order to write byte[] line by line but I didn't find.
Please using this api: DataOutputStream.write.
Answer:<<<api>>>: DataOutputStream.write
<<<code>>>: private void buildByteArrayPart(DataOutputStream dataOutputStream, String parameterName, byte[] parameterValue) throws IOException {
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes(twoHyphens + boundary + lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes("Content-Disposition: form-data; name=" + parameterName + "; filename=\"" + parameterName + "\"" + lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes("Content-Type: application/octet-stream" + lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes("Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary" + lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes(lineEnd);
    dataOutputStream.write(parameterValue);
    dataOutputStream.writeBytes(lineEnd);
}
<<<explanation>>>: Here is how to solve this:
You can write your byte arrays to the file in a loop, and then read them back in a loop. You can use a separator to indicate the end of one byte array and the start of the next. Here's an example:

```java
// Write byte arrays to file
FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream("file.txt");
DataOutputStream dos = new DataOutputStream(fos);
byte[][] byteArrays = { /* your byte arrays here */ };
for (byte[] byteArray : byteArrays) {
    dos.write(byteArray);
    dos.writeByte(/* your separator here */);
}
dos.close();

// Read byte arrays from file
FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("file.txt");
DataInputStream dis = new DataInputStream(fis);
byte[] buffer = new byte[1024];
int bytesRead;
while ((bytesRead = dis.read(buffer)) != -1) {
    byte[] byteArray = new byte[bytesRead];
    System.arraycopy(buffer, 0, byteArray, 0, bytesRead);
    /* process byteArray */
    dis.readByte(); // read separator
}
dis.close();
```

In this example, the separator is a single byte that you choose. You can use any byte that doesn't appear in your data. When you read the byte arrays back in, you read the separator after each byte array.

Please note that this is a simple example and may not work for all cases. For example, if your byte arrays are very large, you may run out of memory when reading them back in. In that case, you would need to write and read them in smaller chunks.

Also, be aware that writing and reading binary data in text format can introduce errors. Always use binary data formats for this purpose.
